instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
Hello friends, I get a Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage in the sectors
<CHIP>U4650</CHIP>
<CHIP>U5000</CHIP>
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

Only with the charger connected the light goes from green to orange and does nothing

I did a thorough check and changed all the damaged components and reballing the <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>
Also reviewing in other posts I saw that they made some measurements in the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> so to advance something I did these measurements

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>

Pin 1 0V
Pin 2 14.6V
Pin 3 3.8V
Pin 9 0.037V
Pin 12 3.4V
Pin 13 3.37V
Pin 14 3.37V
Pin 15 0V
Pin 17 4.04V
Pin 19 5.05V
Pin 20 5.03V
Pin 27 14.4V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> Isn´t present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Start posting diode mode reading at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (red probe at ground).
Check the resistance value between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
Thanks for the welcome, I am very excited as I have experience repairing iPhone and I am just entering the world of Mac

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.122

Resistance between Pins 17/18 =  3.2 ohm
Resistance between Pins 27/28 = 20 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
I'm not sure about the values; diode mode readings?
We need ohm scale measurments; should get very low values, as per schematic.
Check <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 and <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52 with their traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
sorry, I edited the answer with correct information
 
Diode mode <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.122V

Resistance between Pins 17/18 = 3.2 ohm
Resistance between Pins 27/28 = 20 ohm 

<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> = 10 ohm
<RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> = 10.3 ohm

<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> = 2.5 ohm
<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> = 0.2 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
No need to check the resistors, if the asked values are good.

Remove F7140 and check <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> voltage.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7113</RESISTOR> is good, as its traces too.
Check all components and traces related with pins 5, 7, 8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
with F7140 removed 
<CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> = 8.56 V

<RESISTOR>R7113</RESISTOR> is good 

All components and traces related to pins 5, 7 and 8 are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
So you have a problem on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, after F7140.
Resolder F7140 and check voltage on its pin 2.
If still low, check diode mode to ground on all big coils, apart of L7130.
See if any gives the same value as in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
Thank you for your answer but i am a little confused, in Rossmann Repair Training Guide it says 

[LIST]
[*]On Macbook Airs and old Macbook Pro 17” <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.5v when 
[*]the SMC is able to communicate with the ISL, 8.16v when the SMC 
[*]cannot. 
[/LIST]

[LIST]
[*]On Macbook Pros <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.56v when the SMC is able to communicate with the ISL, 12.23v when the SMC cannot.
[/LIST]

taking this into account the voltage of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in the model I'm looking at would be fine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
Your problem is not caused by communication between SMC and <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

You've said to have 4V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, when F7140 is in place.
Confirm if is true...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message: i have 8.57 V in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with F7140 in place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
"Pin 17 4.04V"
We need accurate and consistent information, in order to help you.

Do you now get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>  present
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present

I don´t know if its normal but the line <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_COMP2</SIGNAL> have  2.2V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (using <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button) and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>    3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>   3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>    0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  3.4V

Drop pulse  3.4V to 0.352V when  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> isTrigger

If good, change <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is unstable, shows voltage variations from 0 to 0.125V without trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
if trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> makes no difference and keeps oscillating

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> has 0V and does nothing when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is activated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> has 0 V and does nothing when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is activated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
Then the problem is PCH related.
I suppose <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is steady high and you still note the drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

Check <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
effectively when I activate <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> the pulse is seen in <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> but not in <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> 1.05V

how are they measured of the 4 PCH's RTC signals?

threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with liquid damage
threads.message:
Heat PCH for test; use quality flux, to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath.
Don't need to melt the balls; no more than 180-200 degrees, for 15-20s.
